'''Edward Griffin Beckwith''' (June 25, 1818 – June 22, 1881) was a [[United States Army]] officer who served in the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War]] and who conducted one of the [[Pacific Railroad Surveys]] in the 1850s and became known as the "Explorer of the Central Rockies".<ref name="media.utah.edu" />
==Biography== Beckwith was born on June 25, 1818<ref name="findagrave.com"/> (some report a January birthdate<ref name="MillerSociety1976">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Nyle H.|title=Kansas and the West: bicentennial essays in honor of Nyle H. Miller|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vyKGAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=18 April 2012|date=1 December 1976|publisher=Kansas State Historical Society|isbn=978-0-87726-002-8|pages=33–}}</ref>) in [[Cazenovia, New York]], son of Judge Barak Beckwith, and Polly (Kennedy) Beckwith. He graduated from [[West Point]] in 1842.<ref name="clan.lib.nv.us" />
He served in [[garrison]] at [[Savannah, Georgia]] as a [[second lieutenant]] of the [[3rd Air Defense Artillery Regiment (United States)|Third Artillery]]<ref name="Fielding1993">{{cite book|last=Fielding|first=Robert Kent|title=The Unsolicited Chronicler: An Account of the Gunnison Massacre, Its Causes and Consequences, Utah Territory, 1847–1859 : a Narrative History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-M8YaM87BKYC&pg=PA38|accessdate=18 April 2012|year=1993|publisher=Paradigm Publications|isbn=978-0-912111-38-4|page=38}}</ref> until 1846, when he was appointed for recruiting service. He was promoted [[First lieutenant]] June 18, 1846, and took an active part in the [[Mexican–American War]]; he was present at [[Tampico Affair|Tampico]] and [[Siege of Veracruz|Vera Cruz]].<ref name="WhiteWagner2001">{{cite book|last1=White|first1=David A.|last2=Wagner|first2=Henry Raup|title=Plains & Rockies, 1800–1865: one hundred twenty proposed additions to the Wagner-Camp and Becker bibliography of travel and adventure in the American West : with 33 selected reprints|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YygUAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=18 April 2012|date=November 2001|publisher=Arthur H. Clark Co.|isbn=978-0-87062-311-0}}</ref><ref name="Herringshaw1909">{{cite book|last=Herringshaw|first=Thomas William|title=Herringshaw's national library of American biography: contains thirty-five thousand biographies of the acknowledged leaders of life and thought of the United States; illustrated with three thousand vignette portraits |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=urzTAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=18 April 2012|year=1909|publisher=American Publishers' Association|page=282}}</ref> Beckwith was engaged in the [[Pacific Railroad Surveys|Pacific Railroad Survey]] from 1853 to 1857 with [[John Williams Gunnison]]. Notably, the [[First Transcontinental Railroad]] followed his recommended route.<ref name="media.utah.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.media.utah.edu/UHE/e/EXPLORATION.html|title=Exploration in Utah|publisher=[[University of Utah]]|accessdate=16 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="clan.lib.nv.us" /> His report, which also included an extensive survey of the [[Great Salt Lake]], contained "much information on the plants, animals, climate, and geographical features of the lands he had explored".<ref name="clan.lib.nv.us">{{cite web|url=http://www.clan.lib.nv.us/content.asp?id=24|title=Edward Griffin Beckwith|publisher=Nevada Riches: The Land and People of the Silver State|accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref> He succeeded Gunnison as leader of the survey after his death,<ref name="Society2007">{{cite book|author=Nevada Historical Society|title=Nevada Historical Society quarterly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EmEpAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=18 April 2012|date=1 January 2007|publisher=The Society|page=10}}</ref> and personally recommended the route for the railroad. He was also involved with constructing military roads in [[Nebraska]] and [[Kansas]], between 1857–1859.
Beckwith was promoted captain May 12, 1855, and served during the [[American Civil War]] in the commissary department from 1861 to 1865, with the exception of a few weeks in 1863, when he acted as provost-marshal-general of the department of the Gulf, and again when placed for a short time (August 1863 – January 1864) in command of the defenses of [[New Orleans]]. On February 8, 1864, he was promoted major, and on March 13, 1865, was brevetted lieutenant-colonel, colonel, and brigadier-general of volunteers. He continued in the service of the commissary department until he was mustered out on May 31, 1866.<ref name="Brown1900">{{cite book|last=Brown|first=John Howard|title=Lamb's biographical dictionary of the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mCVAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA245|accessdate=15 April 2012|year=1900|publisher=James H. Lamb Company|pages=245–}}</ref>
==Personal life== Beckwith married Cornelia Williamson (1828–1911), with whom he had a daughter, Madeline Julia Beckwith (1852–1935). He died at [[Clifton, New York]], in 1881, and is buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]].<ref name="findagrave.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=5988355|title=Edward Griffin Beckwith|work=findagrave.com|accessdate=16 April 2012}}</ref>
